elements.content:
<ce:figure id="FIG1">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Basket-like silver cage in Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6CHF<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Ag <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, in which an acetylide ion is symmetrically encapsulated. Ag(I) atoms are drawn as 50% thermal ellipsoids. Selected bond distances (Å). C1–C1a, 1.24(1); C1–Ag1, 2.497(7); C1–Ag2, 2.115(7); C1–Ag3, 2.211(7); C1–Ag4, 2.330(7). Ag⋯Ag, 2.8133(9)–3.2041(8) Å. Symmetry code: (a) 3/2−<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 1−<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  Basket-like silver cage in Ag2C2⋅6CHF2CO2Ag 1, in which an acetylide ion is symmetrically encapsulated. Ag(I) atoms are drawn as 50% thermal ellipsoids. Selected bond distances (Å). C1-C1a, 1.24(1); C1-Ag1, 2.497(7); C1-Ag2, 2.115(7); C1-Ag3, 2.211(7); C1-Ag4, 2.330(7). Ag⋯Ag, 2.8133(9)-3.2041(8) Å. Symmetry code: (a) 3/2-x, 1-y, z.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="FIG4">
<ce:label>Fig. 4</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Centrosymmetric edge-sharing (C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>@Ag<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf> double silver(I) cage in [HPyCH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>OH][Ag<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)(CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>(HPyCH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>OH)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·0.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), each half having the shape of a triangulated dodecahedron. The thermal ellipsoids are drawn at the 35% probability level. Ag⋯Ag distances greater than 3.4 Å are represented by broken open lines. The sivler(I) to acetylide bonds in the left half are omitted for clarity. Selected bond distances: C1–C2, 1.25(1); C1–Ag1, 2.509(8); C1–Ag3, 2.290(7); C1–Ag5, 2.238(8); C1–Ag6, 2.123(7); C1–Ag7, 2.648(8); C2–Ag1, 2.624(8); C2–Ag1a, 2.279(8); C2–Ag2, 2.175(8); C2–Ag3, 2.614(8), C2–Ag4, 2.373(9); C2–Ag7, 2.446(9). Ag⋯Ag, 2.8522(9)–3.379(1) Å. Symmetry code: (a) −<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, −<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, −<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr4"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 4  Centrosymmetric edge-sharing (C2)2@Ag14 double silver(I) cage in [HPyCH2OH][Ag9(C2)(CF3CO2)9(HPyCH2OH)(H2O)]⋅0.5H2O (2), each half having the shape of a triangulated dodecahedron. The thermal ellipsoids are drawn at the 35% probability level. Ag⋯Ag distances greater than 3.4 Å are represented by broken open lines. The sivler(I) to acetylide bonds in the left half are omitted for clarity. Selected bond distances: C1-C2, 1.25(1); C1-Ag1, 2.509(8); C1-Ag3, 2.290(7); C1-Ag5, 2.238(8); C1-Ag6, 2.123(7); C1-Ag7, 2.648(8); C2-Ag1, 2.624(8); C2-Ag1a, 2.279(8); C2-Ag2, 2.175(8); C2-Ag3, 2.614(8), C2-Ag4, 2.373(9); C2-Ag7, 2.446(9). Ag⋯Ag, 2.8522(9)-3.379(1) Å. Symmetry code: (a) -x, -y, -z.

<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">New double salts Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6AgO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CCHF<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [HPyCH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>OH][Ag<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)(CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>(HPyCH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>OH)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·0.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (PyCH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>OH=4-(hydroxymethyl)pyridine) (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·5CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Ag·2MeCN·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) and Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·8CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Ag·2EtCN·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>) have been synthesized by dissolving Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> in an aqueous solution of the corresponding silver salt followed by the addition of an ancillary ligand. Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has a three-dimensional structure in which unprecedented basket-like silver cages are inter-connected by difluoroacetate ligands. In <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, centrosymmetric (C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>@Ag<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf> double cages with each half taking the shape of a triangulated dodecahedron are linked through additional silver atoms to generate an infinite chain, and unsupported silver(I)–silver(I) interactions exist between neighboring chains. Of the two independent 4-(hydroxymethyl)pyridinium ions in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, one acts in the <ce:italic>O</ce:italic>-ligating mode, which is observed for the first time, while the other merely serves to provide charge balance and space-filling. Both <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are layer-type structures in which the basic building unit is a distorted monocapped octahedron and monocapped trigonal prism, respectively.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

New double salts Ag2C2⋅6AgO2CCHF2 (1), [HPyCH2OH][Ag9(C2)(CF3CO2)9(HPyCH2OH)(H2O)]⋅0.5H2O (PyCH2OH=4-(hydroxymethyl)pyridine) (2), Ag2C2⋅5CF3SO3Ag⋅2MeCN⋅2H2O (3) and Ag2C2⋅8CF3SO3Ag⋅2EtCN⋅3H2O (4) have been synthesized by dissolving Ag2C2 in an aqueous solution of the corresponding silver salt followed by the addition of an ancillary ligand. Complex 1 has a three-dimensional structure in which unprecedented basket-like silver cages are inter-connected by difluoroacetate ligands. In 2, centrosymmetric (C2)2@Ag14 double cages with each half taking the shape of a triangulated dodecahedron are linked through additional silver atoms to generate an infinite chain, and unsupported silver(I)-silver(I) interactions exist between neighboring chains. Of the two independent 4-(hydroxymethyl)pyridinium ions in 2, one acts in the O-ligating mode, which is observed for the first time, while the other merely serves to provide charge balance and space-filling. Both 3 and 4 are layer-type structures in which the basic building unit is a distorted monocapped octahedron and monocapped trigonal prism, respectively.

In [HPyCH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>OH][Ag<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)(CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>(HPyCH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>OH)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·0.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (PyCH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>OH=4-(hydroxymethyl)pyridine) (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), centrosymmetric (C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>@Ag<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf> double cages are linked through additional silver atoms to generate an infinite chain, and one of the two independent 4-(hydroxymethyl)pyridinium ions acts in the <ce:italic>O</ce:italic>-ligating mode, which is observed for the first time. Both Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·5CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Ag·2MeCN·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) and Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·8CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Ag·2EtCN·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>) have layer-type structures.</ce:simple-para>

However, the silver–ethynediyl (<ce:sup loc="pre">−</ce:sup>CC<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, acetylide dianion, IUPAC name acetylenediide) interaction is seldom studied till recently  due to the explosive nature of silver acetylide, Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, in the anhydrous state and its insolubility in most solvents, which present serious difficulties in synthesis and characterization. Double salts of silver acetylide have the general formula Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·<ce:italic>m</ce:italic>AgX, where X is the co-existing anion. Previous studies in our laboratory have shown that different kinds of silver cages each encapsulating an acetylide dianion, C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>@Ag<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>=6–9), can be obtained by varying the types of ancillary anions (X=F, ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> or NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>) . In order to study the influence of co-existing anions on the self-assembly of Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-containing systems, we have conducted research on a series of double salts of silver acetylide with silver perfluorocarboxylates , as well as several triple  and quadruple  salts containing these two components. The fluoro-substituted carboxylates (or sulfonate) employed in the synthesis include trifluoroacetate, pentafluoropropionate, trifluoromethanesulfonate (triflate), as well as dicarboxylates such as tetrafluorosuccinate and hexafluoroglutarate . Recently, the influence of neutral ancillary ligands such as aliphatic nitriles  and crown ethers  has been explored, and mixed-valent silver(I,II) compounds have been obtained in the presence of 1,4,8,11-tetramethyl-1,4,8,11-tetraazacyclotetradecane . Furthermore, the role of quaternary ammonium ions as additional components has also been investigated, leading to the generation of some extraordinary structures .<display>

elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Silver alkynyl (R-CC-) compounds have been extensively investigated , and there exist several examples of silver-ethyne (HCCH)  and -ethynyl (HCC-) binding . However, the silver-ethynediyl (-CC-, acetylide dianion, IUPAC name acetylenediide) interaction is seldom studied till recently  due to the explosive nature of silver acetylide, Ag2C2, in the anhydrous state and its insolubility in most solvents, which present serious difficulties in synthesis and characterization. Double salts of silver acetylide have the general formula Ag2C2⋅mAgX, where X is the co-existing anion. Previous studies in our laboratory have shown that different kinds of silver cages each encapsulating an acetylide dianion, C2@Ag n  (n=6-9), can be obtained by varying the types of ancillary anions (X=F, ClO4 or NO3) . In order to study the influence of co-existing anions on the self-assembly of Ag2C2-containing systems, we have conducted research on a series of double salts of silver acetylide with silver perfluorocarboxylates , as well as several triple  and quadruple  salts containing these two components. The fluoro-substituted carboxylates (or sulfonate) employed in the synthesis include trifluoroacetate, pentafluoropropionate, trifluoromethanesulfonate (triflate), as well as dicarboxylates such as tetrafluorosuccinate and hexafluoroglutarate . Recently, the influence of neutral ancillary ligands such as aliphatic nitriles  and crown ethers  has been explored, and mixed-valent silver(I,II) compounds have been obtained in the presence of 1,4,8,11-tetramethyl-1,4,8,11-tetraazacyclotetradecane . Furthermore, the role of quaternary ammonium ions as additional components has also been investigated, leading to the generation of some extraordinary structures .

<ce:para view="all">Herein we report four new double salts of silver acetylide with silver difluoroacetae, trifluoroactate and trifluoromethanesulfonate formulated as Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6CHF<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Ag (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [HPyCH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>OH][Ag<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)(CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>(HPyCH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>OH)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·0.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·5CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Ag·2MeCN·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) and Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·8CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Ag·2EtCN·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>).</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Our synthetic strategy is based on the working hypothesis that depolymerization of silver acetylide occurs upon dissolving in a concentrated aqueous solution of a soluble silver salt to afford various polyhedral C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>@Ag<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>≥6) cage species. The assembly of such C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>@Ag<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> aggregates to form a crystalline complex is dependent on many factors such as co-existing anions, cations and ancillary ligands, as well as the stoichiometric ratios of the reactants.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Our synthetic strategy is based on the working hypothesis that depolymerization of silver acetylide occurs upon dissolving in a concentrated aqueous solution of a soluble silver salt to afford various polyhedral C2@Ag n  (n≥6) cage species. The assembly of such C2@Ag n  aggregates to form a crystalline complex is dependent on many factors such as co-existing anions, cations and ancillary ligands, as well as the stoichiometric ratios of the reactants.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The choice of co-existing fluorocarboxylate in a double salt Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·<ce:italic>m</ce:italic>R<ce:inf loc="post">f</ce:inf>CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Ag is based on the fact that an aqueous solution of R<ce:inf loc="post">f</ce:inf>CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Ag provides a sufficiently high concentration of silver(I) ions requisite for dissolving silver acetylide. The adduct formation of Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> with CHF<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Ag can be carried out readily in aqueous solution in the presence of AgBF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> as a promoter , leading to crystallization of Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6CHF<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Ag <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a very stable phase, and is invariably obtained irrespective of the reaction conditions such as concentration, solvent and even hydrothermal synthesis.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The choice of co-existing fluorocarboxylate in a double salt Ag2C2⋅mRfCO2Ag is based on the fact that an aqueous solution of RfCO2Ag provides a sufficiently high concentration of silver(I) ions requisite for dissolving silver acetylide. The adduct formation of Ag2C2 with CHF2CO2Ag can be carried out readily in aqueous solution in the presence of AgBF4 as a promoter , leading to crystallization of Ag2C2⋅6CHF2CO2Ag 1. Compound 1 is a very stable phase, and is invariably obtained irrespective of the reaction conditions such as concentration, solvent and even hydrothermal synthesis.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Single-crystal X-ray analysis established that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> contains a C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>@Ag<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf> cage as shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG1"></ce:float-anchor>. This cage is in the shape of a basket that is found for the first time, with a twofold axis passing through Ag1 and bisecting the C1–C1a triple bond. Such a cage is more open than the convex polyhedra reported previously. The acetylide dianion is accommodated in the silver basket and symmetrically bound to all seven vertices with Ag–C distances ranging between 2.155(7) and 2.497(7) Å. The C1–C1a bond length 1.24(1) Å is in fair agreement with the triple bond lengths found in acetylene (1.205 Å)  and CaC<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (1.191 Å) . The Ag⋯Ag distances lie in the range 2.8133(9)–3.2041(8) Å, which are shorter than twice the van der Waals radius of silver (3.40 Å) and are comparable to the interatomic contact of 2.89 Å in silver metal , being suggestive of the existence of argentophilic interaction .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Single-crystal X-ray analysis established that 1 contains a C2@Ag7 cage as shown in  . This cage is in the shape of a basket that is found for the first time, with a twofold axis passing through Ag1 and bisecting the C1-C1a triple bond. Such a cage is more open than the convex polyhedra reported previously. The acetylide dianion is accommodated in the silver basket and symmetrically bound to all seven vertices with Ag-C distances ranging between 2.155(7) and 2.497(7) Å. The C1-C1a bond length 1.24(1) Å is in fair agreement with the triple bond lengths found in acetylene (1.205 Å)  and CaC2 (1.191 Å) . The Ag⋯Ag distances lie in the range 2.8133(9)-3.2041(8) Å, which are shorter than twice the van der Waals radius of silver (3.40 Å) and are comparable to the interatomic contact of 2.89 Å in silver metal , being suggestive of the existence of argentophilic interaction .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>@Ag<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf> cages are inter-linked by difluoroacetate ligands to form a 2D network, as shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG2"></ce:float-anchor>. The three independent difluoroacetate ligands can be divided into two types: type (O11) difluoroacetate acting as a bridge within the layer, and the other type (O21 and O31) not only functioning in this manner but also connecting adjacent layers through type Ag5 atoms to generate a 3D structure, as shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG3"></ce:float-anchor>.</ce:para>

The three independent difluoroacetate ligands can be divided into two types: type (O11) difluoroacetate acting as a bridge within the layer, and the other type (O21 and O31) not only functioning in this manner but also connecting adjacent layers through type Ag5 atoms to generate a 3D structure, as shown in  .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The introduction of 4-(hydroxymethyl)pyridine (4-pyridyl carbinol, pyridine-4-methanol, hereafter abbreviated as PyCH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>OH) as an ancillary ligand into the Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>+AgCF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> system led to the isolation of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, which comprises a discrete <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-protonated species [HPyCH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>OH]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> and a polymeric anionic system [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)(CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>(HPyCH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>OH)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>. The basic building unit in the latter is a centrosymmetric double cage with each half taking the shape of a triangulated dodecahedron, as shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG4"></ce:float-anchor>. The polyhedron is composed of two atom sets Ag1Ag1aAg2Ag3 and Ag4Ag5Ag6Ag7, which are each coplanar within 0.002 and 0.022 Å, respectively, making a dihedral angle of 84.7°; this cage also encloses a C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ion.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The introduction of 4-(hydroxymethyl)pyridine (4-pyridyl carbinol, pyridine-4-methanol, hereafter abbreviated as PyCH2OH) as an ancillary ligand into the Ag2C2+AgCF3CO2 system led to the isolation of compound 2, which comprises a discrete N-protonated species [HPyCH2OH]+ and a polymeric anionic system [Ag9(C2)(CF3CO2)9(HPyCH2OH)(H2O)]∞ -. The basic building unit in the latter is a centrosymmetric double cage with each half taking the shape of a triangulated dodecahedron, as shown in  . The polyhedron is composed of two atom sets Ag1Ag1aAg2Ag3 and Ag4Ag5Ag6Ag7, which are each coplanar within 0.002 and 0.022 Å, respectively, making a dihedral angle of 84.7°; this cage also encloses a C2 2- ion.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Silver atoms of type Ag9 are linked to each half of the (C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>@Ag<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf> double cage through bridging by a pair of trifluoacetate ligands, and each Ag9 atom is additionally coordinated by two aqua ligands and the oxygen atom of a terminal 4-(hydroxymethyl)pyridinium ligand, [HPyCH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>OH]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>, at Ag9–O1=2.438(7) Å, and the Ag9–O1–C016 bond angle is 131.8(6)°. The protonated pyridyl nitrogen atom N2 forms a donor hydrogen bond with O2W (1−<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, −1−<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>) at a distance of 2.826 Å. Thus, a building unit is formed as illustrated in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG5"></ce:float-anchor>. Such units are inter-connected by the aqua ligands (on Ag9) to generate a polymeric chain running along the [101̄] direction. A significant feature is that unsupported silver(I)–silver(I) contacts exist between neighboring chains with an Ag8⋯Ag8 (1–<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, −<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, −<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>) distance of 3.384 Å, which is slightly shorter than twice the van der Waals radius of silver (3.4 Å). This along with other precedents of ligand-unsupported Ag(I) aggregates in the literature  provide further corroborative evidence for the importance of argentophilicity. Taking these inter-chain silver(I)–silver(I) contacts into consideration, the crystal structure can be regarded as a layer-type network (
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG6"></ce:float-anchor>). A discrete [HPyCH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>OH]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> cation is accommodated in each rectangular void within the layer and stabilized by hydrogen bonds: O2⋯O11 (−<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, −<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, 1−<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>) 2.764Å, O2⋯O1W (<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, 1+<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>) 2.768 Å and N2⋯O82 (<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, 1+<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>) 2.828 Å.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Silver atoms of type Ag9 are linked to each half of the (C2)2@Ag14 double cage through bridging by a pair of trifluoacetate ligands, and each Ag9 atom is additionally coordinated by two aqua ligands and the oxygen atom of a terminal 4-(hydroxymethyl)pyridinium ligand, [HPyCH2OH]+, at Ag9-O1=2.438(7) Å, and the Ag9-O1-C016 bond angle is 131.8(6)°. The protonated pyridyl nitrogen atom N2 forms a donor hydrogen bond with O2W (1-x, -1-y, z) at a distance of 2.826 Å. Thus, a building unit is formed as illustrated in  . Such units are inter-connected by the aqua ligands (on Ag9) to generate a polymeric chain running along the [101̄] direction. A significant feature is that unsupported silver(I)-silver(I) contacts exist between neighboring chains with an Ag8⋯Ag8 (1-x, -y, -z) distance of 3.384 Å, which is slightly shorter than twice the van der Waals radius of silver (3.4 Å). This along with other precedents of ligand-unsupported Ag(I) aggregates in the literature  provide further corroborative evidence for the importance of argentophilicity. Taking these inter-chain silver(I)-silver(I) contacts into consideration, the crystal structure can be regarded as a layer-type network ( ). A discrete [HPyCH2OH]+ cation is accommodated in each rectangular void within the layer and stabilized by hydrogen bonds: O2⋯O11 (-x, -y, 1-z) 2.764Å, O2⋯O1W (x, y, 1+z) 2.768 Å and N2⋯O82 (x, 1+y, z) 2.828 Å.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The ligand behavior of 4-(hydroxymethyl)pyridine with its ring nitrogen coordinated to a metal center has been documented with structural details in [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(PyCH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(OAc)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]  and with spectroscopic data in K<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>[Co(NO)(CN)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(PyCH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>OH)]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O . However, to our knowledge ligation via the oxygen atom of the <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-protonated form of PyCH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>OH in a metal complex is found for the first time.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The ligand behavior of 4-(hydroxymethyl)pyridine with its ring nitrogen coordinated to a metal center has been documented with structural details in [Cu2(PyCH2OH)2(OAc)4]  and with spectroscopic data in K2[Co(NO)(CN)4(PyCH2OH)]⋅H2O . However, to our knowledge ligation via the oxygen atom of the N-protonated form of PyCH2OH in a metal complex is found for the first time.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">We have previously shown that silver acetylide can form triple salts of the formula Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·AgF·4AgCF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·RCN (R=CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>) displaying honeycomb-like layered structures . However, no double salt of silver acetylide with silver triflate has been reported so far. New double salts <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are now obtained by dissolving silver acetylide in an aqueous solution of silver trifluoromethanesulfonate (triflate) followed by addition of acetonitrile or propionitrile. The main difference in the present procedure from the preparation of the triple salts is that AgBF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> is not used here so that the release of AgF is avoided .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: We have previously shown that silver acetylide can form triple salts of the formula Ag2C2⋅AgF⋅4AgCF3SO3⋅RCN (R=CH3, C2H5) displaying honeycomb-like layered structures . However, no double salt of silver acetylide with silver triflate has been reported so far. New double salts 3 and 4 are now obtained by dissolving silver acetylide in an aqueous solution of silver trifluoromethanesulfonate (triflate) followed by addition of acetonitrile or propionitrile. The main difference in the present procedure from the preparation of the triple salts is that AgBF4 is not used here so that the release of AgF is avoided .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Single-crystal X-ray analysis revealed that Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·5CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Ag·2MeCN·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) has a layered structure that is constructed from a distorted monocapped octahedron. As illustrated in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG7"></ce:float-anchor>(a), atom sets Ag2Ag3Ag4 and Ag5Ag6Ag7 constitute two triangular faces making a dihedral angle of 4.9°. These two faces have a twist angle of about 58°, and atom Ag1 caps the upper triangular face. Atom Ag1 and the centroids of the two triangular faces are almost co-linear (angle about 176°), and a view of the silver cage down its idealized <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> axis is shown in (b). A C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anion is completely encapsulated in this silver cage with π interaction to Ag2 and Ag3 (C2–Ag4 2.853Å is too long to be taken as effective binding) as well as σ bonding to Ag1, Ag5, Ag6 and Ag7. The C(1)–C(2) bond length is 1.17(1) Å, the Ag–C distances fall in the range 2.12(1)–2.607(9) Å, and the Ag⋯Ag distances range from 2.938(1) to 3.332(1) Å.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Single-crystal X-ray analysis revealed that Ag2C2⋅5CF3SO3Ag⋅2MeCN⋅2H2O (3) has a layered structure that is constructed from a distorted monocapped octahedron. As illustrated in  (a), atom sets Ag2Ag3Ag4 and Ag5Ag6Ag7 constitute two triangular faces making a dihedral angle of 4.9°. These two faces have a twist angle of about 58°, and atom Ag1 caps the upper triangular face. Atom Ag1 and the centroids of the two triangular faces are almost co-linear (angle about 176°), and a view of the silver cage down its idealized C 3 axis is shown in (b). A C2 2- anion is completely encapsulated in this silver cage with π interaction to Ag2 and Ag3 (C2-Ag4 2.853Å is too long to be taken as effective binding) as well as σ bonding to Ag1, Ag5, Ag6 and Ag7. The C(1)-C(2) bond length is 1.17(1) Å, the Ag-C distances fall in the range 2.12(1)-2.607(9) Å, and the Ag⋯Ag distances range from 2.938(1) to 3.332(1) Å.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>@Ag<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf> silver cages are linked alternately by a pair of μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-triflate ions and a couple of aqua ligands to generate an infinite chain along the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> direction. Two kinds of μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-triflate ions, bidentate (μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-O,O,O′) and tridentate (μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-O,O′,O″), function as connectors between chains to form a layered network (
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG8"></ce:float-anchor>). A perspective view of the layer viewed along the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> direction is shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG9"></ce:float-anchor>. Each C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>@Ag<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf> cage is terminally coordinated by two acetonitrile ligands. All hydrophobic groups are located in the space between adjacent layers.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The C2@Ag7 silver cages are linked alternately by a pair of μ2-triflate ions and a couple of aqua ligands to generate an infinite chain along the c direction. Two kinds of μ3-triflate ions, bidentate (μ3-O,O,O') and tridentate (μ3-O,O',O"), function as connectors between chains to form a layered network ( ). A perspective view of the layer viewed along the a direction is shown in  . Each C2@Ag7 cage is terminally coordinated by two acetonitrile ligands. All hydrophobic groups are located in the space between adjacent layers.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The compound Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·8CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Ag·2EtCN·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> has also a layered structure, whose basic building unit is a distorted monocapped trigonal prism (
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG10"></ce:float-anchor>). The two triangular faces Ag2Ag3Ag4 and Ag5Ag6Ag7 are almost parallel, making a dihedral angle of 3.1°, with Ag1 capping the upper face. The polyhedron exhibits a pronounced lean to one side, and the enclosed C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> species is π bound to Ag3, Ag4 and Ag5 while σ binding to the remaining silver atoms. The Ag–C distances fall in the range 2.153(9)–2.69(1) Å, and the C(1)–C(2) bond length is 1.18(1) Å. Short Ag⋯Ag distances in this cage occur in the range from 2.853(1) to 3.298(2) Å.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The compound Ag2C2⋅8CF3SO3Ag⋅2EtCN⋅3H2O 4 has also a layered structure, whose basic building unit is a distorted monocapped trigonal prism ( ). The two triangular faces Ag2Ag3Ag4 and Ag5Ag6Ag7 are almost parallel, making a dihedral angle of 3.1°, with Ag1 capping the upper face. The polyhedron exhibits a pronounced lean to one side, and the enclosed C2 2- species is π bound to Ag3, Ag4 and Ag5 while σ binding to the remaining silver atoms. The Ag-C distances fall in the range 2.153(9)-2.69(1) Å, and the C(1)-C(2) bond length is 1.18(1) Å. Short Ag⋯Ag distances in this cage occur in the range from 2.853(1) to 3.298(2) Å.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">An interesting structural feature is that the pair of independent acetonitrile ligands in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are coordinated to silver atoms on opposite sides of the layer in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> (), whereas the independent propionitrile ligands in <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are bound to two neighboring silver atoms and hence situated on the same side of the layer (

elements.clean_text: An interesting structural feature is that the pair of independent acetonitrile ligands in 3 are coordinated to silver atoms on opposite sides of the layer in 3 (), whereas the independent propionitrile ligands in 4 are bound to two neighboring silver atoms and hence situated on the same side of the layer ( ).

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In contrast to the case of triple salts Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·AgF·4AgCF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·RCN (R=CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>) where the ligation of acetonitrile or propionitrile leads to an isomorphous layer-type structure , the ancillary nitrile ligands afford different layer-type structures in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>. With stronger additional binding of fluoride ions between silver cages in the <ce:italic>iso</ce:italic>-structural triple salts, the layer is more robust and thus the terminal coordination sites can be occupied by either acetonitrile or propionitrile without affecting the assembly process and overall crystal packing.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In contrast to the case of triple salts Ag2C2⋅AgF⋅4AgCF3SO3⋅RCN (R=CH3, C2H5) where the ligation of acetonitrile or propionitrile leads to an isomorphous layer-type structure , the ancillary nitrile ligands afford different layer-type structures in 3 and 4. With stronger additional binding of fluoride ions between silver cages in the iso-structural triple salts, the layer is more robust and thus the terminal coordination sites can be occupied by either acetonitrile or propionitrile without affecting the assembly process and overall crystal packing.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Under the consolidatory influence of argentophilicity, namely the d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup>–d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> closed-shell attraction  that promotes the aggregation of silver(I) centers, Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> dissolves readily in a concentrated aqueous solution of a silver salt to generate polyhedral [Ag<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)]<ce:sup loc="post">(<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>−2)+</ce:sup> moieties. The present study shows that the assembly of such species is affected by co-existing anions (CF<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>HCO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>) and ancillary ligands (aqua, aliphatic nitrile and 4-(hydroxymethyl)pyridine) to generate crystal structures exhibiting various cage geometries and network connectivities.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Under the consolidatory influence of argentophilicity, namely the d10-d10 closed-shell attraction  that promotes the aggregation of silver(I) centers, Ag2C2 dissolves readily in a concentrated aqueous solution of a silver salt to generate polyhedral [Ag n (C2)](n-2)+ moieties. The present study shows that the assembly of such species is affected by co-existing anions (CF2HCO2 -, CF3CO2 -, CF3SO3 -) and ancillary ligands (aqua, aliphatic nitrile and 4-(hydroxymethyl)pyridine) to generate crystal structures exhibiting various cage geometries and network connectivities.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The labile nature of the silver acetylide system poses a considerable challenge to designed assembly, and presently it is not yet possible to employ a specific [C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>@Ag<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">(<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>−2)+</ce:sup> species as a polyhedral building block for supramolecular construction, in contrast to structurally robust entities such as the [Re<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>Se<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>] unit . However, the incorporation of 4-(hydroxmethyl)pyridine as a new organic component in compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> broadens the scope of the silver acetylide system through ligand variation. As further studies on analogous organic-inorganic acetylide-encapsulating systems continue to be further developed, it may be possible to gain better insight into the rational design of discrete and extended supramolecular silver complexes.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The labile nature of the silver acetylide system poses a considerable challenge to designed assembly, and presently it is not yet possible to employ a specific [C2@Ag n ](n-2)+ species as a polyhedral building block for supramolecular construction, in contrast to structurally robust entities such as the [Re6Se8] unit . However, the incorporation of 4-(hydroxmethyl)pyridine as a new organic component in compound 2 broadens the scope of the silver acetylide system through ligand variation. As further studies on analogous organic-inorganic acetylide-encapsulating systems continue to be further developed, it may be possible to gain better insight into the rational design of discrete and extended supramolecular silver complexes.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Materials</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">All chemicals were purchased from ACROS and Aldrich and used without further purification. Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> was prepared as described previously . Caution: thoroughly dried Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> detonates easily upon mechanical shock, and only a small quantity should be used in any chemical reaction. Excess amount can be disposed in alkaline solution via slow decomposition .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials

All chemicals were purchased from ACROS and Aldrich and used without further purification. Ag2C2 was prepared as described previously . Caution: thoroughly dried Ag2C2 detonates easily upon mechanical shock, and only a small quantity should be used in any chemical reaction. Excess amount can be disposed in alkaline solution via slow decomposition .

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Synthesis of Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6CHF<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Ag (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Freshly prepared Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> was added to 1 ml of a concentrated aqueous solution of CHF<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Ag and AgBF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> (molar ratio ∼1:1) in a plastic beaker with stirring until saturated. The excess amount of Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> was filtered off, the filtrate was placed in a desiccator charged with P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>. Colorless block-like crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were obtained in ca. 70% yield after several days.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Ag2C2⋅6CHF2CO2Ag (1)

Freshly prepared Ag2C2 was added to 1 ml of a concentrated aqueous solution of CHF2CO2Ag and AgBF4 (molar ratio ~1:1) in a plastic beaker with stirring until saturated. The excess amount of Ag2C2 was filtered off, the filtrate was placed in a desiccator charged with P2O5. Colorless block-like crystals of 1 were obtained in ca. 70% yield after several days.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Synthesis of [HPyCH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>OH][Ag<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)(CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>(HPyCH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>OH)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·0.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> was added to 1 ml of an aqueous solution of CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Ag (0.442 g, 2 mmol) and AgBF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> (0.389 g, 2 mmol) in a plastic beaker with stirring until saturated. The excess amount of Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> was filtered off, and 50 mg PyCH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>OH was added to the filtrate. The resulting suspension was transferred to a thick-walled glass tube. The tube was subsequently flame-sealed and kept in a furnace at 115<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 6 h, and then cooled down to room temperature (r.t.) at 6° h<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. Colorless prismatic crystals of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were isolated in good yield (>50%). Anal. Found: C, 17.02; H, 0.77; N, 1.15. Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">32</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">19</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">21.5</ce:inf>F<ce:inf loc="post">27</ce:inf>Ag<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>: C, 17.01; H, 0.85; N, 1.24%.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [HPyCH2OH][Ag9(C2)(CF3CO2)9(HPyCH2OH)(H2O)]⋅0.5H2O (2)

Ag2C2 was added to 1 ml of an aqueous solution of CF3CO2Ag (0.442 g, 2 mmol) and AgBF4 (0.389 g, 2 mmol) in a plastic beaker with stirring until saturated. The excess amount of Ag2C2 was filtered off, and 50 mg PyCH2OH was added to the filtrate. The resulting suspension was transferred to a thick-walled glass tube. The tube was subsequently flame-sealed and kept in a furnace at 115°C for 6 h, and then cooled down to room temperature (r.t.) at 6° h-1. Colorless prismatic crystals of 2 were isolated in good yield (>50%). Anal. Found: C, 17.02; H, 0.77; N, 1.15. Calc. for C32H19N2O21.5F27Ag9: C, 17.01; H, 0.85; N, 1.24%.

The excess amount of Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> was filtered off, and a few drops of MeCN were added to the filtrate. (Note: excess MeCN would lead to deposition of Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> as a white precipitate.) The resulting solution was placed in a desiccator charged with P<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>. Colorless block-like crystals of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were obtained in ca. 20% yield after several days.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Ag2C2⋅5CF3SO3Ag⋅2MeCN⋅2H2O (3)

Compound 3 was prepared by adding Ag2C2 to 1 ml of a concentrated aqueous solution of 1.5 g CF3SO3Ag in a plastic beaker with stirring until saturated. The excess amount of Ag2C2 was filtered off, and a few drops of MeCN were added to the filtrate. (Note: excess MeCN would lead to deposition of Ag2C2 as a white precipitate.) The resulting solution was placed in a desiccator charged with P2O5. Colorless block-like crystals of 3 were obtained in ca. 20% yield after several days.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Synthesis of Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·8CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Ag·2EtCN·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Compound <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> was synthesized by repeating the procedure for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> but with propionitrile used instead of acetonitrile.</ce:para><ce:para view="all">Complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are stable in the dark, and compounds <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are highly hygroscopic. All four complexes decompose readily in common solvents such as water, ethanol and acetonitrile. The homogeneity of each crystalline compound was indicated by its uniform habit, which was confirmed by measuring the unit-cell data of several hand-picked crystals.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Ag2C2⋅8CF3SO3Ag⋅2EtCN⋅3H2O (4)

Compound 4 was synthesized by repeating the procedure for 3 but with propionitrile used instead of acetonitrile.

Complexes 1 and 2 are stable in the dark, and compounds 3 and 4 are highly hygroscopic. All four complexes decompose readily in common solvents such as water, ethanol and acetonitrile. The homogeneity of each crystalline compound was indicated by its uniform habit, which was confirmed by measuring the unit-cell data of several hand-picked crystals.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>X-ray crystallography</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">A selected single crystal of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> or <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> was sealed in a glass capillary and mounted on a Bruker SMART 1000 CCD diffractometer operating at 50 kV and 30 mA using Mo–K<ce:inf loc="post">α</ce:inf> radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>=0.71073 Å). Data collection and reduction were performed using the <ce:small-caps>smart</ce:small-caps> and <ce:small-caps>saint</ce:small-caps> software , with frames of 0.3° oscillation in the <ce:italic>θ</ce:italic> range 1.5<<ce:italic>θ</ce:italic><28°. An empirical absorption correction was applied using the <ce:small-caps>sadabs</ce:small-caps> program . For <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, a single crystal sealed in a capillary was used for data collection on a Rigaku RAXIS IIC imaging plate diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo–K<ce:inf loc="post">α</ce:inf> radiation from a rotating-anode generator powered at 50 kV and 90 mA. ABSCOR correction was applied . The structures were solved by direct methods and all non-hydrogen atoms were subjected to anisotropic refinement by full-matrix least squares on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> using the <ce:small-caps>shelxtl</ce:small-caps> package . In <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, the oxygen atoms of one triflate ion are disordered over two sets of positions; in <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, one aqua ligand also exhibits disorder over two positions. The crystal data and details of refinement are summarized in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="TBL1"></ce:float-anchor>, and selected bond distances and angles are listed in the legends for figures.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography

A selected single crystal of 1, 2 or 3 was sealed in a glass capillary and mounted on a Bruker SMART 1000 CCD diffractometer operating at 50 kV and 30 mA using Mo-Kα radiation (λ=0.71073 Å). Data collection and reduction were performed using the smart and saint software , with frames of 0.3° oscillation in the θ range 1.5<θ<28°. An empirical absorption correction was applied using the sadabs program . For 4, a single crystal sealed in a capillary was used for data collection on a Rigaku RAXIS IIC imaging plate diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation from a rotating-anode generator powered at 50 kV and 90 mA. ABSCOR correction was applied . The structures were solved by direct methods and all non-hydrogen atoms were subjected to anisotropic refinement by full-matrix least squares on F 2 using the shelxtl package . In 3, the oxygen atoms of one triflate ion are disordered over two sets of positions; in 4, one aqua ligand also exhibits disorder over two positions. The crystal data and details of refinement are summarized in  , and selected bond distances and angles are listed in the legends for figures.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Ag2C2⋅6CHF2CO2Ag (1)

Freshly prepared Ag2C2 was added to 1 ml of a concentrated aqueous solution of CHF2CO2Ag and AgBF4 (molar ratio ~1:1) in a plastic beaker with stirring until saturated. The excess amount of Ag2C2 was filtered off, the filtrate was placed in a desiccator charged with P2O5. Colorless block-like crystals of 1 were obtained in ca. 70% yield after several days.

Synthesis of [HPyCH2OH][Ag9(C2)(CF3CO2)9(HPyCH2OH)(H2O)]⋅0.5H2O (2)

Ag2C2 was added to 1 ml of an aqueous solution of CF3CO2Ag (0.442 g, 2 mmol) and AgBF4 (0.389 g, 2 mmol) in a plastic beaker with stirring until saturated. The excess amount of Ag2C2 was filtered off, and 50 mg PyCH2OH was added to the filtrate. The resulting suspension was transferred to a thick-walled glass tube. The tube was subsequently flame-sealed and kept in a furnace at 115°C for 6 h, and then cooled down to room temperature (r.t.) at 6° h-1. Colorless prismatic crystals of 2 were isolated in good yield (>50%). Anal. Found: C, 17.02; H, 0.77; N, 1.15. Calc. for C32H19N2O21.5F27Ag9: C, 17.01; H, 0.85; N, 1.24%.

Synthesis of Ag2C2⋅5CF3SO3Ag⋅2MeCN⋅2H2O (3)

Compound 3 was prepared by adding Ag2C2 to 1 ml of a concentrated aqueous solution of 1.5 g CF3SO3Ag in a plastic beaker with stirring until saturated. The excess amount of Ag2C2 was filtered off, and a few drops of MeCN were added to the filtrate. (Note: excess MeCN would lead to deposition of Ag2C2 as a white precipitate.) The resulting solution was placed in a desiccator charged with P2O5. Colorless block-like crystals of 3 were obtained in ca. 20% yield after several days.
